[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ii', 'to': 'ai', 'str': 'ai for ii', 'is_documented': False, 'description': None}, {'type': 'delete', 'from': 'i', 'str': 'i deleted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'e', 'to': 'ē', 'str': 'ē for e', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'This is a common feature of vowel quantity change observed in Indian manuscripts. It particularly affects final ē, which tends to be shortened to e due to recitation habits. This is considered not merely a quantitative alteration, but also a qualitative shift where the original more open ē transitions to a closer e. This pattern of shortening is prevalent across various Indian manuscript lineages'}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'x́', 'to': 'xᵛ', 'str': 'xᵛ for x́', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'Velar fricative confusion: x́ replaces xᵛ, especially in Indian manuscripts.'}, {'type': 'replace', 'from': 'ā', 'to': 'ā̊', 'str': 'ā̊ for ā', 'is_documented': True, 'description': 'This is a well-documented orthographic feature in Iranian manuscripts, reflecting a tendency for the letter ā̊ to disappear by evolving into ā. This change is particularly prevalent in later Iranian copies from the 19th century, where ā replaces ā̊ in a high percentage of occurrences (over 75% in some manuscripts). Possible reasons suggested include Indian influence or erroneous transcription. In contrast, Indian manuscripts exhibit different behaviours for ā̊, such as its use for āu or its graphical representation as ā/ə in line-breaks, implying a pronunciation similar to /āo/ or /āe/'}]

[{'type': 'insert', 'to': 'a', 'str': 'a inserted', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "In Indian manuscripts, anaptyxis (vowel insertion) is very frequent, especially in consonantal clusters involving sonorants (m, n, r). The usual anaptyctic vowel is a. Examples include sar for sr, man for mn, xaš for xš. Less commonly, ə or i can be inserted in hr clusters. This is influenced by Gujarati's tendency to avoid complex consonant clusters and prefer open syllables.In Iranian manuscripts, syncope (vowel deletion) is frequent, particularly of short vowels in the first syllables of polysyllabic words. This is attributed to the 'allegro' (fast) pronunciation in regions like Yazd. Common positions for syncope include before r (e.g., srəδanąmca for sarəδanąmca), before semivowels (ii, uu), and after h. i deletion is part of this phenomenon."}]

[{'type': 'replace', 'from': 'a', 'to': 'ə', 'str': 'ə for a', 'is_documented': True, 'description': "This occurs in Iranian manuscripts, although i for ə is more common in Yazdi manuscripts, and e for ə in Kermani manuscripts.
